body:
> 
> 
> See https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-4759

I would rebase this PR after THRIFT-4759 is solved.

We're moving towards cmake but it's going to take a while to get everything that autoconf does for us working in cmake... in the meantime thanks for both.  The "make dist" job in Travis CI failed and it looks related.

> 
> 
> We're moving towards cmake but it's going to take a while to get everything that autoconf does for us working in cmake... in the meantime thanks for both. The "make dist" job in Travis CI failed and it looks related.

I forgot to change autotool scripts,I will re-push it.
AppVeyor issue is the concurrency test failure, unrelated.
@jeking3 by the way,are there any plans to merge fbthrift code?

> 
> 
> Long term, we really should put THRIFT_EXPORT on all classes, and disable global visibility on unixy builds like boost does, that way unix and windows are playing the same export game.

That is a huge work,and I found little UNIX/Linux cpp projects limiting symbol visibility.It is a good idea except to make code a little ugly.
Boost leads the way in terms of correctness here, just a suggestion for long term.

I think I prefer the other PR for this issue.  We don't use autoconf for any build that needs dllimport/export - we only use cmake.  Therefore a cmake-centric solution is appropriate, especially if nobody wants to tackle symbol visibility on non-windows systems right now.

Looks like more work is needed; perhaps you forgot to add the directory where the generated header is placed during the build?

Also you may need to disable the concurrency_test in the appveyor.yml for now, see my change in #1716 to appveyor.yml: https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/1716/files#diff-180360612c6b8c4ed830919bbb4dd459 - we've had a lot of appveyor failures since committing the C++11 code; I documented it in THRIFT-4739.
How will this interact with #1713?
Interesting! The build works for me locally, but then again I do not build all possible thrift languages. I'll check it and get back to you.

The build looks good now for at least two platforms on AppVeyor. I'm testing again with your change in #1716 to appveyor.yml: https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/1716/files#diff-180360612c6b8c4ed830919bbb4dd459 and lets see if that helps to get any further. Thanks!

> 
> 
> We're moving towards cmake but it's going to take a while to get everything that autoconf does for us working in cmake... in the meantime thanks for both. The "make dist" job in Travis CI failed and it looks related.
AppVeyor passed,Travis CI failed for networking problems.
fbthrift code changes would need to be submitted by the fbthrift team.  We cannot pull them in.
Both MSVC builds on appveyor right now use BUILD_SHARED_LIBS=OFF.  The MSVC2017 one should be changed in appveyor.yml.

https://bugs.python.org/issue29413 shows that default (and not controllable) behavior for unwrap forces it to wait for a proper shutdown.  Nobody does this really... What I have done is added a very, very small timeout (0.001 seconds) to essentially force unwrap() so it does not block reading for something that may never come.  We do our best and then close the socket.

The build did not go any further with the change. But it does run through on at least 2 platforms, one of which is MSVC. I can also confirm the shared library build works for me on MSVC 2015 and MSVC 2017 Windows 7 x64.
Can the PR progress?

Not when it breaks the build for reasons related to the code submitted.  In this case, cygwin was busted by the changes.

https://ci.appveyor.com/project/ApacheSoftwareFoundation/thrift/builds/21911295/job/ekouonlbymt2q155#L2605
Oh I see, I assumed its unrelated. I'll check it tomorrow.
So that's pretty bizarre on the perl, looking at the master version of the Makefile.am in compiler/cpp, it is definitely included; however in the build output I don't see t_perl anywhere.
Needs some more work, as it broke the build.
If you rebase on master, the build is fairly clean at this point and master has 5 successful builds in a row.
I suppose instead of just applying the patch and de-boosting it, I should have actually tried it locally!

> How will this interact with #1713?

I can't think of a reason why it would. They both create files in ${CMAKE_BINARY_DIR}, but I don't know what else is similar about them?
Could we add a html test of the compiler output somewhere?
Any chance we could fix the delegating constructor mess? :)

I'd prefer those things go into the same commit but if you want to add a second PR with "[ci skip]" at the end of the commit message and pull request title, addressing the three things I mentioned, that would be okay too.  You did get a clean build after all.

Ok I'm at a real loss as to why the build fails on Cygwin for me, but works for #1714. I think the diff-set is mostly identical and I did not touch the failing Cygwin sources. Is it possible that I hit a random bug in Cygwin?

Cygwin's a different beast, using windows-y rules but with a unix toolchain.  Usually you can "just build like it's unix" but not always.  I suggest cleaning up all the travis failures first.... then see if cygwin is still a problem.
@Jens-G there are 4 commits, so be sure to use the Squash and Merge button.  I approved it, but you can merge it and resolve the ticket. :)
I see that a significant number of builds uses autotools, is that correct? Supporting autotools would require a different mechanism, so possibly #1714 could be simpler for that scenario.
ok, thanks!
Reopened, will shepherd this through.

I am adding the necessary test and changes in {{test/Makefile.am}} for this. It caught the {{}} issue before applying the fix. I will push to your branch to kick off another build. This was caused by a missing test case, as most bogs are, so adding a test is the best way to make sure it stays fixed.
I rebased on master to fix up CI issues, if they are not caused by the patch.
Not sure cygwin should matter here since it uses unix tooling and gcc with visibility on symbols?
I prefer this one where the file is generated and used.

> 
> 
> Ok I'm at a real loss as to why the build fails on Cygwin for me, but works for #1714. I think the diff-set is mostly identical and I did not touch the failing Cygwin sources. Is it possible that I hit a random bug in Cygwin?

I failed  on Cygwin on the first commit ,then I used "if defined(_MSC_VER )" instead of _win32 to check msvc compiler .
But now that the header is generated by cmake,this may be a cmake bug of failing to detect the correct platform.

> 
> 
> Not sure cygwin should matter here since it uses unix tooling and gcc with visibility on symbols?

Given that cmake has full support for windows,we could drop cygwin support.
We don't have cygwin support because of autotools.  We have it because folks still use it and we want to prove we can build on it.

> I prefer this one where the file is generated and used.

I agree. But how could autotools use the header that is cmake-generated? I see these options:
1. Generate the same header also from autotools. This would be possible but I'm not an expert how to do this.
2. Make the shared library build only available with cmake, and provide a dummy header for autotools that defines the `THRIFT_EXPORT` defines as empty dummies. CMake can place the generated header higher in the search path than the dummy header to be sure the correct one is used.
3. Pre-generate the header twice, once for shared and once for static library build, and store both headers in the source repository as verbatim copies. Then pick the matching header at configure time.

I'm not very fond of either of these choices. If anything then number (2) seems the most feasible and least invasive. But it brings quite some confusion about the duplicate header, and its possible that people will ask for shared library builds from autotools too.

What do yo think?
@jeking3 I fixed all three issues as listed above (extended changelog and added Breaking-Change label)

Sorry, misclick.
Please, ignore
We are using cmake to build on cygwin, so it should work.

> We are using cmake to build on cygwin, so it should work.

My comment is not specific to cygwin. If the export-header is cmake-generated, then autotools-users will not have it. That will break *all* non-cmake-based builds.
autotools based builds using gcc or clang have default global visibility and therefore should not be affected.  I must be missing something on my end...  Please explain.

The problem is that in every source file where symbols should explicitly be exported, we need to do two things:

1. Include the export header: `include "thrift/thrift_export.h"`
2. Add the export definition: `class THRIFT_EXPORT SomeClass {`

Both changes will break autotools builds. Autotools would not have the header and would not have the `THRIFT_EXPORT` definition. We would need to provide some drop-in replacement for both.
You can have autotools generate a header that defines THRIFT_EXPORT as nothing and make it part of the distribution....
This is my suggestion number (2) from above, yes. Its certainly possible, but I'm not an autotools expert so I won't be able to implement that myself.
I'll try to help out with that.
It would be better to just add the header to source than modify autotools to generate it.Then just use my PR.
Thanks @jeking3 !
We need to change the build tooling to prove this out.  I will do that and push into your branch to kick another build.  This PR built with java-8-openjdk, not java-11-openjdk.

Thanks for the quick response @jeking3 

The CI is now failing because there is no JDK:
```
-- ----------------------------------------------------------
-- Thrift version:                               0.13.0 (0.13.0)
-- Thrift package version:                       0.13.0
-- Build configuration Summary
--   Build compiler:                             ON
--   Build libraries:                            ON
--   Build tests:                                ON
--   Build type:                                 Debug
--  Language libraries:
--   Build as3 library:                          ON
--   Build C++ library:                          ON
--     C++ Language Level:                       C++11 [compiler must support it]
--   Build C (GLib) library:                     ON
--   Build Java library:                         OFF
--    - Java Runtime missing
--   Build Python library:                       ON
--   Build Haskell library:                      ON
--  Library features:
--   Build shared libraries:                     ON
--   Build with libevent support:                ON
--   Build with Qt5 support:                     ON
--   Build with ZLIB support:                    ON
-- ----------------------------------------------------------
```
I've added the JDK-11 to the build.
I see, bionic only came with the jre11.  Thanks.  (next time put it in alphabetically!!)
Looks like the file debian/control needs to be updated for this...

Thanks for the pointer @jeking3. I'll get rid of the jdk7 since the target is 1.8 as well: https://github.com/apache/thrift/blob/99f673a767104a037e24eb10e1f3341e0ab428f4/lib/java/gradle/sourceConfiguration.gradle#L48-L49

I'll also plug in the headless ones, since we don't use any GUI:
```
root@06e6d3dc7505:/thrift# apt-cache search openjdk
icedtea-8-plugin - web browser plugin based on OpenJDK and IcedTea to execute Java applets
jtreg - Regression Test Harness for the OpenJDK platform
openjdk-8-dbg - Java runtime based on OpenJDK (debugging symbols)
openjdk-8-demo - Java runtime based on OpenJDK (demos and examples)
openjdk-8-doc - OpenJDK Development Kit (JDK) documentation
openjdk-8-jdk - OpenJDK Development Kit (JDK)
openjdk-8-jdk-headless - OpenJDK Development Kit (JDK) (headless)
openjdk-8-jre - OpenJDK Java runtime, using Hotspot JIT
openjdk-8-jre-headless - OpenJDK Java runtime, using Hotspot JIT (headless)
openjdk-8-jre-zero - Alternative JVM for OpenJDK, using Zero/Shark
openjdk-8-source - OpenJDK Development Kit (JDK) source files
openjdk-8-jre-dcevm - Alternative VM for OpenJDK 8 with enhanced class redefinition
uwsgi-plugin-jvm-openjdk-8 - Java plugin for uWSGI (OpenJDK 8)
uwsgi-plugin-jwsgi-openjdk-8 - JWSGI plugin for uWSGI (OpenJDK 8)
uwsgi-plugin-ring-openjdk-8 - Closure/Ring plugin for uWSGI (OpenJDK 8)
uwsgi-plugin-servlet-openjdk-8 - JWSGI plugin for uWSGI (OpenJDK 8)
openjdk-11-dbg - Java runtime based on OpenJDK (debugging symbols)
openjdk-11-demo - Java runtime based on OpenJDK (demos and examples)
openjdk-11-doc - OpenJDK Development Kit (JDK) documentation
openjdk-11-jdk - OpenJDK Development Kit (JDK)
openjdk-11-jdk-headless - OpenJDK Development Kit (JDK) (headless)
openjdk-11-jre - OpenJDK Java runtime, using Hotspot JIT
openjdk-11-jre-headless - OpenJDK Java runtime, using Hotspot JIT (headless)
openjdk-11-jre-zero - Alternative JVM for OpenJDK, using Zero
openjdk-11-source - OpenJDK Development Kit (JDK) source files
```
I'll omit 9 and 10 since they are already EOL: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_version_history
I've also listed the dependencies alphabetically :-)

I'm seeing some errors:
```
^[[4mRunning "qunit:ThriftDeepConstructor" (qunit) task^[[24m
^[[31m>> ^[[39mThere was an error with headless chrome
^[[31mFatal error: Failed to launch chrome!
/thrift/src/lib/js/node_modules/puppeteer/.local-chromium/linux-609904/chrome-linux/chrome: error while loading shared libraries: libasound.so.2: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
```

Our tests load chrome, but something isn't loading libasound.  This also happens when you install Visual Studio Code on ubuntu.  You can add the libasound2 package to the dockerfile.  I would prefer if we use java-11-openjdk-headless...
Do we also need something for a TLS socket?
I prefer using the headless as well. I've added libasound2 package to the Dockerfile.

Still some issues with launching Chrome:
```
^[[4mRunning "qunit:ThriftDeepConstructor" (qunit) task^[[24m
^[[31m>> ^[[39mThere was an error with headless chrome
^[[31mFatal error: Failed to launch chrome!
/thrift/src/lib/js/node_modules/puppeteer/.local-chromium/linux-609904/chrome-linux/chrome: error while loading shared libraries: libatk-bridge-2.0.so.0: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
```

Another one:
```
/thrift/src/lib/js/node_modules/puppeteer/.local-chromium/linux-609904/chrome-linux/chrome: error while loading shared libraries: libgtk-3.so.0: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
```
@jeking3 can you restart the failed builds? The error looks unrelated.

Dear @jeking, I usually prefer the same as you suggest, to rely on the build tools for auto-generated headers. But after thinking for a while I agree with @cyyever that *if* you need to support autotools, then his PR is better. Its much easier to understand his PR, and both systems would consistently use the same header.

@jfarrell The PyPI admins have received a request to expand the maintainer list for the [PyPI thrift project](https://pypi.org/project/thrift/) in order to upload 0.12.0 Could you please respond to https://github.com/pypa/warehouse/issues/5346 ?
This has broken the CI builds.  It looks like the java runs slower than expected... I think we need to adjust the timeouts on the cross test builds.
I just pushed a fix by increasing the ruby client timeout.
Thanks, @jeking3 I accidentally force pushed, and therefore discarded your commit.

@Jens-G I added you for review because this is the last item in thrift under these tickets, but it isn't a comprehensive fix.  It is an improvement, and I think we should merge it, but I'm wondering if we need to open a new ticket to enforce thrift file naming rules, for example "(using developer-speak for a minute) the filename must contain only isalnum() characters".

@jeking3 I would say it is a restriction that one (developer) should be able to live with. 

Does the `namespace` declaration interefere with this for python? I mean, If I declare a `namespace py foobar`, that would override the generated file / folder name, right? How about that?
If it does then the fix isn't valid.
Also rebase on master which is more stable... I fixed the concurrency_test.
Looking forward, thanks!

> 
> 
> Looking forward, thanks!

wait for a moment.

> 
> 
> Also rebase on master which is more stable... I fixed the concurrency_test.

just rebase on master.I am not familiar with appveyor scripts.

In the file appveyor.yml there is a directive that sets the MSVC 2017 build to static.  Change it.  None of the windows MSVC build tested your changes because both of them disable shared library builds.

> 
> 
> In the file appveyor.yml there is a directive that sets the MSVC 2017 build to static. Change it. None of the windows MSVC build tested your changes because both of them disable shared library builds.

fixed
When can this be expected? That is, when is 0.13 planned? :)
We just made a release on January 4.  Best guess right now would be around summer, but it could be sooner if we come to a consensus on it.  I'd love to get to 3 releases yearly if we could.
Merged #1714 instead of this one.
Whoops I closed the wrong one.
Merged #1714 instead of this one.
A reminder this needs to be rebased.
THRIFT-4759 was solved, please rebase and continue. :)
Thanks for merging it. Could we have it back ported to 0.9.x?

The project generally does not provide that service.  However...

There's an open request to backport a CVE for SASL to 0.9.3 and release a 0.9.3.1 specifically for Java, and release it to Maven Central.  We could include this into that work.  I'll link them together.
That's great! Thanks a lot!
Does this close THRIFT-4732 or is there more work to do?
I should rebase on master.

> 
> 
> Does this close THRIFT-4732 or is there more work to do?

To complete THRIFT-4732,I need another PR.
Sorry @jeking3 - been super busy after work for the past month :/
Looking now
@MikailBag All of the rust builds are failing, unfortunately. I suspect this is because the Rust version has to be bumped as well for the new clippy attributes to be understood.
Recommend building locally with the docker container before pushing up to CI...
Oh, it seems that new syntax was only introduced in rustc v1.31, which was published 2018-12-06.
If you can make it backwards compatible, great, otherwise we can't accept something that would push the minimum required version forward that far.
Ok. Than I think I should close this PR, because I can't make changes backwards-compatible, and suppressing the lint is easy.
Ugh, concurrency_test, why!!!
